Question 1: A patient presents with the following skin finding. You would advise supplementation with 
which of the following?

options.c: Vitamin B complex and vitamin K
options.d: Safflower oil and vitamin B complex

questions.explanation:
The image shows rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of 
safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex. Phrynoderma or toad skin is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis. It is caused by a deficiency 
of vitamin E, B, A, C, and essential fatty acids.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following has the highest content of thiamine?
questions.explanation:
Gingelly (sesame) seeds have the highest content of thiamine. The thiamine content in various foods in decreasing order are as follows: • Gingelly seeds • Groundnut • Bengal gram • Whole wheat • Raw rice Thiamine is lost from rice during the process of milling. As it is a water-soluble vitamin, washing, 
and cooking rice cause further losses. Hence, it is advisable to avoid highly polished rice and eat 
parboiled or under-milled rice.

Question 3: 485 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presented with loose stools and skin rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Diet history 
revealed that the patient had been consuming a jowar-rich diet since childhood. This 
condition results due to excess of which amino acid in the diet?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pellagra. It is caused by the excess of leucine in jowar. Excess of leucine in jowar (sorghum) and maize interferes with the conversion of tryptophan to 
niacin causing pellagra. It presents with the following features: • Diarrhea • Dermatitis (sun-exposed areas) 490 
Sold by @itachibot • Dementia People consuming jowar also have a higher risk of developing genu valgum and osteoporosis due 
to greater retention of ingested fluoride.
